sn47.37:4.1: “Mendicants, there are these four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
sn47.37:4.3: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body, keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn47.37:4.4: As they do so they give up desire for the body.
sn47.37:4.5: When desire is given up they realize the deathless.
sn47.37:5.1: They meditate by observing an aspect of feelings, keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn47.37:5.2: As they do so they give up desire for feelings.
sn47.37:5.3: When desire is given up they realize the deathless.
sn47.37:6.1: They meditate by observing an aspect of the mind, keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn47.37:6.2: As they do so they give up desire for the mind.
sn47.37:6.3: When desire is given up they realize the deathless.
sn47.37:7.1: They meditate by observing an aspect of principles, keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn47.37:7.2: As they do so they give up desire for principles.
sn47.37:7.3: When desire is given up they realize the deathless.”
